title: Why is it acceptable for champs that are slated for a rework to be weak for years?
body:
This was something I couldn't really wrap my head around when it comes to balance.  Leaving something intentionally weak just gives players a noobtrap to pick from until it's "fixed" and that can take north of a year, sometimes two years (or even longer).

I get that when strong said champs are "unfun", but isn't that true for any champ that's over-the-top strong?  I don't care if a lee sin (not slated for rework) is too strong or a darius (slated for rework).  Anything being too strong relative to the field is annoying to be against.  Even those who are going to get reworks still deserve to be at least respectable picks in the interim.  It's only fair to players who enjoy those edge champs and bought skins for them.

TL;DR - OP doesn't like that champions who are fundamentally broken get gutted until they eventually get a rework.

That said, Poppy has been widely considered 'Underpowered' for years and Maknoon embarrassed a whole heap of Challenger Tier players with her the other day in the NA Expansion Tournament.

What champ isn't "fundamentally broken" when it's too strong?  Hell, what champs aren't "fundamentally broken" when you just look at their kits in a vaccuum?  I hear a ton about broken mechanics but I haven't heard one thing about a universally recognized healthy champ.

> What champ isn't "fundamentally broken" when it's too strong?

Broken champs are broken regardless of power level.  Generally, what you're looking for in a broken champion is something that's bad for game health even when it's balanced.  You're also looking for champions that ignore fundamental principles of the game design.  

For example, {{champion:45}} is broken because long range instant stun into 100-0 combo affords no meaningful counterplay -- either it kills you and Veigar is good, or it doesn't and Veigar sucks.  So long as the play pattern remains the same, this mechanic is broken regardless of what the numbers are.  Riot chooses to leave the numbers too low to be a competitive pick, because broken UP is less bad for the game than broken OP.

> Hell, what champs aren't "fundamentally broken" when you just look at their kits in a vaccuum?  

About 90% of them.  Most of the time people misuse the term "broken" and apply it to things like {{champion:236}}.  That's just an overtuned champion, meaning his numbers were too big to be balanced but making them smaller would result in him being good for the game.

> I hear a ton about broken mechanics but I haven't heard one thing about a universally recognized healthy champ.

I don't think you can get universal agreement on anything.  That's just the nature of people.

Here are some paragons of health to consider: {{champion:99}} {{champion:110}} {{champion:267}}

I found it amusing that the post right above yours has veigar and udyr as healthy champs.

But I still disagree about 90% of the pool and including veigar in that 10%.  I mean just off the top of my head there's a number that you'd be hard pressed to find a hell of a lot of players defending that exceeds 10%: {{champion:266}} {{champion:84}} {{champion:53}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:28}} {{champion:105}} {{champion:41}} {{champion:121}} {{champion:82}} {{champion:20}} {{champion:78}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:2}} {{champion:13}} {{champion:35}} {{champion:27}} {{champion:18}} {{champion:23}} {{champion:6}} {{champion:67}} {{champion:8}} {{champion:19}} {{champion:83}} {{champion:115}} {{champion:26}} {{champion:126}} 

I imagine you could nit pick a few of them, but this is just off the top of my head as  an illustration/example that there's more than 10%.  By my rough estimation it's about over 20% of the pool, counting veigar who you opted to include.  It's not a hard and fast list, however - just something off the top of my head so please don't say 1-2 shouldn't be included which makes the whole list moot.

Meanwhile even if say all of those mentioned (or even most) were peeled back then we'd just move on to something else being inherently toxic for the game like {{champion:32}} {{champion:412}} {{champion:154}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:429}} etc.

I really think that "healthy" champs are in the minority and tend to be lower mobility picks like the paragons of health you described.

> I imagine you could nit pick a few of them, but this is just off the top of my head as  an illustration/example that there's more than 10%.  

Generally, I think you are conflating "broken" and "toxic".

"Broken" means "violates fundamental principles of the game design".  From your list, I would label the following as broken:
{{champion:28}} - Her design was made in the era of invisible pink wards and now her stealth mechanic is no longer compatible with the modern vision mechanics.
{{champion:78}} - Her ultimate breaks the rules of teamfighting and towers.

"Toxic" means "creates more anti-fun than fun in the game".  {{champion:53}} is an example of a toxic champion.  There's nothing unhealthy about his design, but the way he tosses hook after hook after hook, and how the counterplay is to dodge all of them, it creates bad feels for many players.

As a rule, any champion that draws a lot of bans without being that strong is probably toxic.  Somewhere around 1/4 to 1/3 of the cast is toxic.

> I really think that "healthy" champs are in the minority and tend to be lower mobility picks like the paragons of health you described.

Here are some examples of healthy mobile champions:
{{champion:103}} {{champion:42}} {{champion:79}} {{champion:59}}

There are tons more, to be clear, just wanted to get a bit concrete.  Here are some key questions to answer on champion health:

* Does the champion have clear strengths and weaknesses?
* Can the champion outplay and be outplayed?
* Does the champion pay a satisfactory cost when misusing one of their abilities?

> What champ isn't "fundamentally broken" when it's too strong?  Hell, what champs aren't "fundamentally broken" when you just look at their kits in a vaccuum?  I hear a ton about broken mechanics but I haven't heard one thing about a universally recognized healthy champ.

I believe people are saying that Udyr and Veigar are healthy champions.

That's what I've heard anyways...

Is the champion toxic (or commonly held to be so by a large majority of the playerbase and/or Riot)?
Has the champion been repeatedly nerfed to the effect and/or with the intent of preventing their competitive viability?

If the answer to *either* of those questions is 'yes', then the champion probably needs a rework.

In Teemo's case, the answer to *both* of those questions appears to be 'yes'.

I personally hate turrets having AA and beam. Because by balancing it Riot had to take more than half of turrets AA damage and turn it into laser beam damage. Thus trough whole game turrets damage is totally worthless. And they live long enough for just 1 beam.

Before, when turrets had only AA their damage was worth something. Now? 18 lvl 600 ap and turret still AAs for ~30 damage (while ofc beam deals amazing dmg)...

I dunno man, My turrets tend to last long enough in fights for a couple beams, and their autos are still around 100 per shot late game. This isn't counting things like on-hits or the ult turret. 

To show some math for this, lvl 18 at 600 AP

>Per shot = 35+.15AP

>Per shot = 35+ .15 * 600

>Per shot = 35+ 90

>Per shot = 125 Damage, before MR.

Considering  that this is at an Attack speed of 1.75, and lets say 1 team fight lasts 6 seconds, your turret, if left alone, should get a total of 9 attacks off, for a total of 1125 potential damage. That isn't shabby, and that is just 1 regular turret *without* the lazar. 
---
As far as squishiness goes the math is as follows. Let's again assume lvl 18 with 600 AP

> Turret HP = 125 + (25*lvl) + (.4*AP)

> Turret HP = 125 + (25*18) + (.4*600)

> Turret HP = 125 + 450 + 200

> Turret HP = 775 HP

Keep in mind this is 775 HP with 80 Armor and 65 Magic Resistance on 1 regular turret. Again, Not shabby if you place them smartly.

---

This has been an ongoing problem that they didn't properly address for years. The issue is that they should have redirected more effort to this and done it earlier. The two champions a month after the 70-80 mark was a mistake, they should have throttled champion release to 1 a month years ago, and focused on reworking and remaking existing champions concurrently.

The effort they are giving now is exactly what they should have been doing two years ago, now they are just really behind and flooded with champions which makes it too hard to maintain.

The other problem is that they have some unhealthy agendas that prioritize Esports over healthy gameplay. Esports is an insignificant fraction of the player base, making changes based on how 0.001% of the players experience the game is flawed. On the opposite side of the spectrum though is the newb catering changes which are designed to satisfy the bulk of unskilled players so they can draw in New players.

That is a problem because plenty of healthy champions are branded toxic just because players who don't even know how to play are unsatisfied... These nerfs account for most of the ez mode champions which were nerfed into oblivion even though they were balanced. They need to stop that nonsense honestly. The game needs more modes and methods of play outside of the regular competition, bots make a good alternative for bad players, but like many strategy games, there should be a suite of single player content, not just to offer some content variety, but also to present new players with a battery of challenges to train themselves and qualify their abilities.

Now more than ever, there are entirely too many champions for new players to learn, let alone try. A good single player experience could be designed to let players experience dozens of champions in concert and learn how to operate tactics from unit control, skill use, opponent negotiation and so on. Without that, they will have this broken gap between the competitive balance of the game, and entry level expectation for new players. Balance decisions can not be made for uneducated players...
